All vaccinated people are now eligible for an additional dose, considering that older people who received the vaccine earlier have been given a chance to recieve the additional dose.     A vaccination campaign for those aged 5-11 is awaiting approval by the European Medicines Agency. This vaccination will be voluntary    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127092653/https://www.commissioner.brussels/en/updates-covid-19/item/888-covid-updates-17-11

An additional dose of the vaccine is now recommended for the whole population. Following the approval recieved from the European Medicines Agency,  the Consultative Committee has asked that the Supreme Health Council and the Advisory Committee on Bioethics give their opinion on a date to start vaccinating 5- to 11-year-olds on a voluntary basis.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127094244/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/news/occ-2611/

In order to expand the immunity of the population and protect the most vulnerable people against the virus, the vaccination must take place over three phases, depending on the number of available doses.    GROUP 1a    In the first instance, the most vulnerable and exposed people will receive the vaccine.    Residents and employees in residential care centres and collective care institutions: since the outbreak of the pandemic, COVID-19 has hit the elderly particularly hard, principally those in residential care centres. They will be vaccinated first, then the corresponding staff (including volunteers), followed by collective care institutions.  Medical personnel from first-line care and hospitals: they are in close contact with COVID-19 patients every day. To protect them, they will be prioritised for vaccination.  The other staff in hospitals and healthcare centres will be vaccinated, including organisations which work in prevention activities, such as vaccination centres and cancer screening centres, Child and Family and ONE.  GROUP 1b : vulnerable people without acute medical issues, but at high risk    In this phase, priority was given to people outside hospitals, who are at the highest risk. It concerns the following groups:    People over the age of 65 : people older than 65 will be a priority in this phase. We have started with the oldest people and then go down through the age groups.  Patients aged 18 to 64 with: â¢ chronic kidney disease present for at least 3 months â¢ chronic liver disease present for at least 6 months â¢ haematological cancers (eg leukemia) â¢ down syndrome â¢ transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) â¢ impaired immune system i.e. suffer from an immunodeficiency or take immunosuppressants â¢ active HIV/AIDS â¢ Some rare diseases belonging to the official lists of rare diseases  Patients aged 45 to 64 with: â¢ Chronic severe respiratory disease â¢ chronic cardiovascular disease â¢ obesity (obesity) with BMI = 30 â¢ diabetes type I and II â¢ chronic nervous system disorders â¢ dementia â¢ cancer (tumours) no more than 5 years ago â¢ elevated blood pressure at least 14O mmHG systolic or at least 90 mmHg diastolic    Pregnant women: to be vaccinated as a priority, they must contact their regular GP. Only their GP can add them. Pregnant women who do not yet have a GP should consult one.    Critical functions: In this phase people who fulfill an essential function will be vaccinated. This concerns a limited group of public order services with high-risk contacts (i.e. the intervention units of the police).    penitentiary officers    (para)olympic athletes and the Red Devils who participated in the European Championship    People aged 12 to 18 with the following risk factors (since June 2021, see below for procedure): *chronic kidney disease for at least 3 months *chronic liver disease for at least 6 months *haematological cancers (eg leukemia) *down syndrome *transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) *impaired immune system i.e. suffering from immunodeficiency or use of immunosuppressants *active HIV/AIDS *Some rare disorders (see Orphanet list: https://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/Disease_Search_List.php?lng=EN).    GROUP 2 - broader population from 12 years old    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212151840/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/vaccination/

This concerns a limited group of public order services with high-risk contacts (i.e. the intervention units of the police).    penitentiary officers    (para)olympic athletes and the Red Devils who participated in the European Championship    People aged 12 to 18 with the following risk factors (since June 2021, see below for procedure): *chronic kidney disease for at least 3 months *chronic liver disease for at least 6 months *haematological cancers (eg leukemia) *down syndrome *transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) *impaired immune system i.e. suffering from immunodeficiency or use of immunosuppressants *active HIV/AIDS *Some rare disorders (see Orphanet list: https://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/Disease_Search_List.php?lng=EN). An additional dose of the vaccine is now recommended for the whole population. Following the approval recieved from the European Medicines Agency,  the Consultative Committee has asked that the Supreme Health Council and the Advisory Committee on Bioethics give their opinion on a date to start vaccinating 5- to 11-year-olds on a voluntary basis.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127094244/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/news/occ-2611/

GROUP 1a    In the first instance, the most vulnerable and exposed people will receive the vaccine.    Residents and employees in residential care centres and collective care institutions: since the outbreak of the pandemic, COVID-19 has hit the elderly particularly hard, principally those in residential care centres. They will be vaccinated first, then the corresponding staff (including volunteers), followed by collective care institutions.  Medical personnel from first-line care and hospitals: they are in close contact with COVID-19 patients every day. To protect them, they will be prioritised for vaccination.  The other staff in hospitals and healthcare centres will be vaccinated, including organisations which work in prevention activities, such as vaccination centres and cancer screening centres, Child and Family and ONE.  GROUP 1b : vulnerable people without acute medical issues, but at high risk    In this phase, priority was given to people outside hospitals, who are at the highest risk. It concerns the following groups:    People over the age of 65 : people older than 65 will be a priority in this phase. Only their GP can add them. Pregnant women who do not yet have a GP should consult one.    Critical functions: In this phase people who fulfill an essential function will be vaccinated. This concerns a limited group of public order services with high-risk contacts (i.e. the intervention units of the police).    penitentiary officers    (para)olympic athletes and the Red Devils who participated in the European Championship    People aged 12 to 18 with the following risk factors (since June 2021, see below for procedure): *chronic kidney disease for at least 3 months *chronic liver disease for at least 6 months *haematological cancers (eg leukemia) *down syndrome *transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) *impaired immune system i.e. suffering from immunodeficiency or use of immunosuppressants *active HIV/AIDS *Some rare disorders (see Orphanet list: https://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/Disease_Search_List.php?lng=EN). All vaccinated people are now eligible for an additional dose, considering that older people who received the vaccine earlier have been given a chance to recieve the additional dose.     A vaccination campaign for those aged 5-11 is awaiting approval by the European Medicines Agency. This vaccination will be voluntary    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127092653/https://www.commissioner.brussels/en/updates-covid-19/item/888-covid-updates-17-11

An additional dose of the vaccine is now recommended for the whole population. Following the approval recieved from the European Medicines Agency,  the Consultative Committee has asked that the Supreme Health Council and the Advisory Committee on Bioethics give their opinion on a date to start vaccinating 5- to 11-year-olds on a voluntary basis.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127094244/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/news/occ-2611/

This concerns a limited group of public order services with high-risk contacts (i.e. the intervention units of the police).    penitentiary officers    (para)olympic athletes and the Red Devils who participated in the European Championship    People aged 12 to 18 with the following risk factors (since June 2021, see below for procedure): *chronic kidney disease for at least 3 months *chronic liver disease for at least 6 months *haematological cancers (eg leukemia) *down syndrome *transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) *impaired immune system i.e. suffering from immunodeficiency or use of immunosuppressants *active HIV/AIDS *Some rare disorders (see Orphanet list: https://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/Disease_Search_List.php?lng=EN).    GROUP 2 - broader population from 12 years old    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211115220254/https://www.info-coronavirus.be/en/vaccination/

GROUP 1a    In the first instance, the most vulnerable and exposed people will receive the vaccine.    Residents and employees in residential care centres and collective care institutions: since the outbreak of the pandemic, COVID-19 has hit the elderly particularly hard, principally those in residential care centres. They will be vaccinated first, then the corresponding staff (including volunteers), followed by collective care institutions.  Medical personnel from first-line care and hospitals: they are in close contact with COVID-19 patients every day. To protect them, they will be prioritised for vaccination.  The other staff in hospitals and healthcare centres will be vaccinated, including organisations which work in prevention activities, such as vaccination centres and cancer screening centres, Child and Family and ONE.  GROUP 1b : vulnerable people without acute medical issues, but at high risk    In this phase, priority was given to people outside hospitals, who are at the highest risk. It concerns the following groups:    People over the age of 65 : people older than 65 will be a priority in this phase. We have started with the oldest people and then go down through the age groups.  Patients aged 18 to 64 with: â¢ chronic kidney disease present for at least 3 months â¢ chronic liver disease present for at least 6 months â¢ haematological cancers (eg leukemia) â¢ down syndrome â¢ transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) â¢ impaired immune system i.e. suffer from an immunodeficiency or take immunosuppressants â¢ active HIV/AIDS â¢ Some rare diseases belonging to the official lists of rare diseases  Patients aged 45 to 64 with: â¢ Chronic severe respiratory disease â¢ chronic cardiovascular disease â¢ obesity (obesity) with BMI = 30 â¢ diabetes type I and II â¢ chronic nervous system disorders â¢ dementia â¢ cancer (tumours) no more than 5 years ago â¢ elevated blood pressure at least 14O mmHG systolic or at least 90 mmHg diastolic    Pregnant women: to be vaccinated as a priority, they must contact their regular GP. Only their GP can add them. Pregnant women who do not yet have a GP should consult one.    Critical functions: In this phase people who fulfill an essential function will be vaccinated. This concerns a limited group of public order services with high-risk contacts (i.e. the intervention units of the police).    penitentiary officers    (para)olympic athletes and the Red Devils who participated in the European Championship    People aged 12 to 18 with the following risk factors (since June 2021, see below for procedure): *chronic kidney disease for at least 3 months *chronic liver disease for at least 6 months *haematological cancers (eg leukemia) *down syndrome *transplant patients (including those on the waiting list) *impaired immune system i.e. suffering from immunodeficiency or use of immunosuppressants *active HIV/AIDS *Some rare disorders (see Orphanet list: https://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/Disease_Search_List.php?lng=EN). An additional dose of the vaccine is now recommended for the whole population. Group classes for adults in language centers, educational centers, and other training centers and schools are suspended. Conducting face-to-face group classes for children in language centers, educational centers, personal development support centers and other training centers and schools is allowed provided at a physical distance of at least 1.5 m and not more than 5 people in a room, wearing protective face masks, hand hygiene, regular airing every hour and disinfection. Restrictions do not apply to special education support centers. The present learning process in the higher schools is terminated. Learning for students from 1-12th grade is suspended. Students from 5-12tth grade must wear a mask in class.   https://archive.vn/QUcwF

The holding of congress-conference events, seminars, symposiums, trainings, competitions, exams and other group events of this nature is suspended. Teambuilding and other organized group events of this nature in work teams are suspended. Employers and recruitment bodies to organize the work process of employees in remote form (distance work / home work), where possible, allowing the presence of at most 50% of the staff. Working hours are between 7.30 am and 10.00 am. 50% of staff must be remote unless impossible. Essential workers but have valid vaccination, illness, or testing documents.   https://archive.vn/QUcwF
No change.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211025203023/https://coronavirus.bg/bg/merki/ogranichitelni-merki

The holding of all mass events, such as music and other festivals, fairs, folklore initiatives and others of such nature, shall be suspended. Visits to libraries, museums, galleries, cinemas, theaters, circus performances, concerts and other indoor performances are suspended. Visits to gambling halls, casinos and food and entertainment establishments within the meaning of Art. 124 of the Tourism Act, including those to the places of accommodation. Visits to shopping malls, shops with a net retail area of ??over 300 square meters, bazaars and indoor exhibitions shall be suspended. Exceptions are allowed for shops offering mainly groceries, pharmacies, drugstores, opticians, pet shops, banks, postal and courier service providers, insurers, payment service providers and telecommunications offices.   https://archive.vn/QUcwF

The test must be taken within 48 hours before arrival if traveling from somewhere in Europe or 72 hours if arriving from outside Europe.    Cabin and freight crews, diplomats, foreign military personnel stationed in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and passengers transiting the country do not need to provide a negative test. Citizens of Croatia, Serbia, and Montenegro and their immediate families can enter without a negative COVID-19 test result, provided they are entering from their country of citizenship.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129233047/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/549896/bosnia-and-herzegovina-authorities-maintaining-covid-19-related-restrictions-nationwide-as-of-nov-26-update-34    https://web.archive.org/web/20211129230641/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No policy change. "Foreign nationals without proof of a recognized vaccination seeking to travel to Switzerland from a SEM high-risk country for a stay here of up to three months without a visa and who do not meet any of the requirements under "Who is permitted to enter Switzerland?" are not permitted to enter Switzerland. These persons include:    -Persons who wish to obtain services in Switzerland;  -Tourists, visitors and participants in events;  -Persons who wish to come to Switzerland for medical treatment that has not yet begun or that is not regarded as urgently required;  -Persons seeking employment or who have been invited for a job interview in Switzerland;  -Persons who wish to submit an application for a residence permit.    A detailed list of the countries exempt from restrictions and an informative graphic can be found in the link below.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211116185435/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/empfehlungen-fuer-reisende/quarantaene-einreisende.html

Although the Swiss government was already restricting travel from certain high-risk destinations, it has further tightened travel limitations starting on November 26th. Specifically, it has intensified restrictions for travelers coming from South African countries amid concerns about the new variant. Target group 1: People at especially high risk, from age 16  Target group 2: Healthcare professionals with patient contact/carers for people at especially high risk  Target group 3: Close contacts (household members or relatives providing care) of people at especially high risk, particularly people with a weakened immune system, from age 16  Target group 4: People in communal facilities with an increased risk of infection and outbreaks (for example homes for the people with disabilities), age 16 to 64  Target group 5: Adults (age 16 to 64) who do not fall into target groups 1 to 4  Target group 6: Adolescents (age 12 to 15) who wish to be vaccinated  http://web.archive.org/web/20210709105625/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html    Especially high risk:  Older people  Pregnant women  Adults with Trisomy 21  Adults with certain forms of chronic conditions

The costs of a COVID-19 vaccination are covered by mandatory health insurance.   The vaccination is thus free of charge for people with mandatory health insurance in Switzerland.   Also free of charge if:  You live in Switzerland and, for example, work for a diplomatic or consular representation or an international organisation.  You live in Switzerland as an employee on secondment, a student or pensioner.  You are a cross-border commuter and are exposed to a risk of infection at work (e.g. healthcare personnel with patient contact or care staff in retirement and care homes).  For these groups the costs of the COVID-19 vaccination will be covered by the Swiss federal government.    The costs will not be covered if you are not in one of the groups of people described above.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210424202000/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/en/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/impfen.html#-134524438

The employee could not perform work due to the quarantine order according to the relevant legal regulations.   The maximum amount of support: 80% of the paid salary (incl. Contributions), the maximum monthly amount of the contribution per employee is CZK 39,000.   The contribution will continue to be provided only to those employees whose employment lasts at least three months as of the date of submission of the monthly statement of paid wages  https://web.archive.org/web/20210827231544/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/compensation/antivirus-plus-forced-limitations-service-operation-and-quarantine

This compensation applies to cases where employees are ordered to quarantine or to be isolated due to COVID-19. The amount of the support is set at 80% of eligible costs (compensation of wages paid to employees + the corresponding amount of statutory contributions), but a maximum of CZK 39,000 per employee and month. For employees, this means that they are in obstacles and receive a wage compensation of 60% of average earnings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211213105600/https://covid.gov.cz/en/situations/compensation/antivirus-plus-forced-limitations-service-operation-and-quarantine

Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately.    Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to be tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 months.    Two weekly test are recommended in municipalities and parishes with high infection rates.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127102306/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately. Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to be tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 12 months. Two weekly test are recommended in municipalities and parishes with high infection rates.    Corona passport is required at educational institutions such as universities, youth education and language schools    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202160355/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

Children in primary school will be sent home from Wednesday 15 December 2021 until (and including) Tuesday 4 January 2022. Pupils in boarding schools and independent vocational schools will be sent home from Sunday 19 December 2021 to (and including) Friday 7 January 2021.    While in school, however, Children and parents who have symptoms of COVID-19 are encouraged to follow the general recommendation to keep children home from school and get tested immediately. Pupils from 1st grade onwards and staff in primary and lower secondary school are strongly encouraged to get tested on a weekly basis, unless they are fully vaccinated or previously infected with COVID-19 within the last 6 months. Two weekly tests are recommended in municipalities and parishes with high infection rates.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216151102/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

A COVID certificate or similar document that proves vaccination, previous infection with COVID or  a recent negative test is needed for entry into certain restaurants, nightlife and some culture venues.    People who attend work physically are advised not to go their workplace if they  experience COVID 19 symptoms and to get tested.       Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127102306/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

From 26 November 2021 employees in the state and the regions are required to present coronapas. Physical attendance at the workplace is the rule unless otherwise agreed with the employer.  Corona passes are needed when attending a conference, unless the organizer ensures that there are 100 or fewer spectators / participants indoors and 1,000 or fewer spectators / participants outdoors. There are special recommendations for testing of staff in geriatric care as well as staff in primary schools who have not been vaccinated or previously infected (within the last 6 months).    At discos and nightclubs you must present corona passport/COVID Certificate or similar. Face masks are not required.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202160355/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

It is adviced to work at home extensively in both public and private workplaces and that meetings, seminars etc. are held virtually. It is adviced to cancel major social events at workplaces, including Christmas lunches. Municipal employers can require their employees to present a corona passport/COVID certificate. Employers may also, under certain conditions, require employees to be tested for corona and disclose the result of the test. However, employers must be able to objectively justify that a test is necessary to limit the spread of infection with COVID-19. Employees in the state and the regions will be required to present a corona passport/COVID certificate. A corona passport/COVID certificate when attending a conference, unless the organizer ensures that there are 100 or fewer spectators/participants indoors and 1,000 or fewer spectators/participants outdoors.    Discos, nightclubs and partybusses are closed, while bars must close at midnight.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212155303/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

It is adviced to work at home extensively in both public and private workplaces and that meetings, seminars etc. are held virtually.  It is adviced to cancel major social events at workplaces, including Christmas lunches. Discos and nightclubs are closed. Bars must close at midnight. 1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen, OECD countries or  COVID-19 risk countries, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test within 24 hours after arrival    2) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. Those with a valid certificate of vaccination are also exempted    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211115181454/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/categorization-of-countries

1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen, OECD countries or  COVID-19 risk countries, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected must take a test before/within 24 hours after arrival.    2) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. Those with a valid certificate of vaccination are also exempted    3)  People coming in from areas with COVID-19 variants of concern within 10 days prior to the date of entering Denmark, must take a test within 24 hours of entry and immediately self-isolate for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least four days after arrival. Those who  have stayed in a country, region or area with COVID-19 variants of concern between 5 and 10 days before entry to Denmark, can interrupt the isolation by a negative PCR test, which is performed immediately after entry, and otherwise with a negative PCR test, which is performed at the earliest on the fourth day after entry    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127110428/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/categorization-of-countries

1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen, OECD countries or  COVID-19 risk countries, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected must take a test before/within 24 hours after arrival.    2)  People coming in from areas with COVID-19 variants of concern within 10 days prior to the date of entering Denmark, must take a test within 24 hours of entry and immediately self-isolate for 10 days. The isolation may be ended with a negative PCR-test taken at least six days after arrival. 1. Residents in nursing homes, assisted living, etc.    2. People aged = 65 who receive both personal care and practical assistance.    3. People aged = 85 years.    4. Personnel in healthcare, elderly care and selected parts of the social sector who are at particular risk of infection or who has been identified as performing a critical function in society.    5. Selected persons with conditions and diseases that result in a significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19.    6. Selected relatives of individuals at significantly increased risk of a severe illness from COVID-19 or relatives who are indispensable as caregivers.    7. People aged 80-84.    8. People aged 75-79.    9. People aged 65-74.    10 A. People aged 60-64 (born between 1957 and 1961).    10 B. People aged 55-59 (born between 1962 and 1966).    10 C. People aged 50-54 (born between 1967 and 1971).    10 D1. People aged 16-19 and 45-49 years (born 1972-1976 and 2002-2005).    10 D2. People aged 20-24 and 40-44 years (born 1977-1981 and 1997-2001).    10 D3. People aged 25-29 and 35-39 years (born 1982-1986 and 1992-1996).    10 D4. People aged 30-34 (born 1987-1991).    11. People aged 12-15 (born 2006-2009). Children, who turn 12 in 2021 will be invited by date of birth and as they turn 12.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202162815/https://www.sst.dk/en/English/Corona-eng/Vaccination%20against%20COVID-19/Who%20should%20be%20vaccinated

1. Residents in nursing homes, assisted living, etc.    2. People aged = 65 who receive both personal care and practical assistance.    3. People aged = 85 years.    4. Personnel in healthcare, elderly care and selected parts of the social sector who are at particular risk of infection or who has been identified as performing a critical function in society.    5. Selected persons with conditions and diseases that result in a significantly increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19.    6. Selected relatives of individuals at significantly increased risk of a severe illness from COVID-19 or relatives who are indispensable as caregivers.    7. People aged 80-84.    8. People aged 75-79.    9. People aged 65-74.    10 A. People aged 60-64 (born between 1957 and 1961).    10 B. People aged 55-59 (born between 1962 and 1966).    10 C. People aged 50-54 (born between 1967 and 1971).    10 D1. People aged 16-19 and 45-49 years (born 1972-1976 and 2002-2005).    10 D2. People aged 20-24 and 40-44 years (born 1977-1981 and 1997-2001).    10 D3. People aged 25-29 and 35-39 years (born 1982-1986 and 1992-1996).    10 D4. People aged 30-34 (born 1987-1991).    11. People aged 12-15 (born 2006-2009). Children, who turn 12 in 2021 will be invited by date of birth and as they turn 12. The Nationwide Telework recommendation has now been reintroduced in areas currently experiencing increased levels of community transmission.   The recommendation is for all employees in the public sector to work remotely as extensively as possible if their duties so allow. The Government also recommends that private employers adopt similar extensive remote work practices, recognising, however, that workplaces will determine how to combine in-office and remote work in a way that ensures health security.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216145328/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/10623/government-recommends-remote-work-in-areas-in-the-community-transmission-phase-until-further-notice

In the area of ??the Hospital Districts of Southern Ostrobothnia and Central Ostrobothnia, an indoor event of up to of 100 people may be held, if:    1) there are auditoriums where no seating is provided for all participants,  or   2) there are joint singing events belonging to public events.   Other types of public events and general meetings are allowed. The organizer of the events described above may introduce a corona passport as an alternative to the existing corona restrictions, in which case the passport will allow admission to events and activities.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211115172413/https://avi.fi/usein-kysyttya-koronaviruksesta

In Southwest Finland, indoor events is restricted to 50 people however, the event organizer may introduce a corona passport as an alternative to the restrictions, in which case the passport will allow admission to events and activities. Other types of public events and general meetings are allowed. Other types of public events and general meetings are allowed. The organizer of the events described above may introduce a corona passport as an alternative to the existing corona restrictions, in which case the passport will allow admission to events and activities. Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211118023844/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory    The Finnish Institute of Health and Welfare recommends avoiding all travel to South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Lesotho, Eswatini (Swaziland), Malawi and Mozambique based on the new COVID-19 variant (B.1.1.529)    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211127120233/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory    The Finnish Institute of Health and Welfare has restricted all travel to South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Lesotho, Eswatini (Swaziland), Malawi and Mozambique based on the new COVID-19 variant (B.1.1.529) from 27th November. Entry from these regions is also restricted and only allowed under certain circumstances.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211212152923/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212153700/https://raja.fi/en/guidelines-for-border-traffic-during-pandemic

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory    The Finnish Institute of Health and Welfare has restricted all travel to South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Lesotho, Eswatini (Swaziland), Malawi and Mozambique based on the new COVID-19 variant (B.1.1.529) from 27th November. Entry from these regions is also restricted and only allowed under certain circumstances. The amendment to the unemployment benefit legislation will be extended until 30 November 2021. Those laid off temporarily and the lay-off started on or after 16 March 2020, are eligible for an unemployment benefit even if they are studying. This is a temporary change that will be effective until 31 December 2021.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211017165013/https://www.kela.fi/web/en/unemployment-benefit-corona

Testing is recommended not only for those who are symptomatic, but also for those among these group who have been exposed to the virus:  those who are unvaccinated, those have received only one vaccine dose of a series of two doses, those are fully vaccinated but less than a week has elapsed since the second dose of the vaccine and have been exposed to coronavirus within the last two weeks, and those who belong to a group for which a third dose of vaccine is recommended, but you have not yet received a third dose.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202170009/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/symptoms-and-treatment-coronavirus/coronavirus-tests

Testing is generally available but specificall recommended not only for those who are symptomatic, but also for those among these group who have been exposed to the virus: those who are unvaccinated, those have received only one vaccine dose of a series of two doses, those are fully vaccinated but less than a week has elapsed since the second dose of the vaccine and have been exposed to coronavirus within the last two weeks, and those who belong to a group for which a third dose of vaccine is recommended, but you have not yet received a third dose.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211202170009/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/symptoms-and-treatment-coronavirus/coronavirus-tests

A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with.      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210820141655/https://koronavilkku.fi/en

The Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare recommends that COVID-19 vaccinations are offered to different groups in the following order:    1. Health care personnel caring for COVID-19 patients, personnel and residents in round-the-clock care units, other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care, and election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting  1.1. Personnel in intensive care units    1.2. Personnel in hospital wards and emergency care for diagnosed or suspected COVID-19 patients    1.3. Personnel at facilities for diagnosed or suspected COVID-19 patients, coronavirus testing personnel, and laboratory personnel involved in coronavirus diagnostics    1.4. Personnel and residents in social services for residential care and enhanced institutional, round-the-clock care units    1.5. Other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care    In group 1.5, a limited number of social welfare and health care personnel working in functions that are considered urgent and critical by the region can be vaccinated against COVID-19. These functions are essential for guaranteeing the patientsâ statutory right to urgent treatment.    Such groups of essential personnel include:    Acute psychiatry unit personnel  Essential staff for units providing urgent care (such as round-the-clock emergency clinics and daytime emergency clinics)  Surgical and operative unit personnel providing emergency or urgent care  Personnel providing emergency or urgent care at wards  Personnel dealing with births  Personnel at emergency social work for substance abuse   Personnel at emergency services for child welfare  1.6. Election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting    As of 19 April 2021, according to an amendment to the Government decree, the election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting in the 2021 municipal elections will be treated as section 1 of the vaccination order.    This group includes the chairpersons, vice-chairpersons, members and deputy members of the electoral committees referred to in section 15 of the Election Act (714/1998) and the electoral commissioners responsible for at-home voting referred to in section 17.    Election boards are not included in this group.    2. The elderly, and persons with underlying conditions that predispose to severe COVID-19  Elderly persons are at the greatest risk for severe COVID-19 disease. Certain underlying conditions also predispose to severe COVID-19.    2.1. = 80-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*                  2.2. 75â79-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*    2.3. 70â74-year-olds, and carers living in the same household    2.4. 12â69-year-olds with a highly predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    2.5. 12â69-year-olds with a predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    * When vaccinating persons aged 70 or over, all those aged 70 or over living in the same household can be vaccinated at the same time when the oldest member of the household is eligible for vaccination, if this is feasible with regard to practical arrangements.    THL recommends that persons in terminal care should not be vaccinated. A decision on the vaccination of persons with fragile health is always made on a case-by-case basis in cooperation with the treating physician, the person being vaccinated and their family members.    Coronavirus vaccination order for risk groups    Press release 5.2.2021: THL has detailed medical risk groups for coronavirus vaccines     3. Others  According to a Government decree that entered into force on 19 April 2021, the rest of the population will be vaccinated by age group starting from the oldest age group.    3.1. 60â69-year-olds    3.2. 50â59-year-olds    3.3. 40â49-year-olds    3.4. 30â39-year-olds    3.5. 16â29-year-olds    3.5. 12â15-year-olds    Social welfare and health care personnel not included in groups 1.1â1.5 are vaccinated based on age along with the rest of the population.     Children under the age of 12 are not yet vaccinated, as no coronavirus vaccine in use has yet been authorised for children under that age.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211118025346/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/vaccines-and-coronavirus/vaccination-order-and-at-risk-groups-for-covid-19

The elderly, and persons with underlying conditions that predispose to severe COVID-19  Elderly persons are at the greatest risk for severe COVID-19 disease. Certain underlying conditions also predispose to severe COVID-19.    2.1. = 80-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*                  2.2. 75â79-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*    2.3. 70â74-year-olds, and carers living in the same household    2.4. 12â69-year-olds with a highly predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    2.5. 12â69-year-olds with a predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    * When vaccinating persons aged 70 or over, all those aged 70 or over living in the same household can be vaccinated at the same time when the oldest member of the household is eligible for vaccination, if this is feasible with regard to practical arrangements.    THL recommends that persons in terminal care should not be vaccinated. Personnel in intensive care units    1.2. Personnel in hospital wards and emergency care for diagnosed or suspected COVID-19 patients    1.3. Personnel and residents in social services for residential care and enhanced institutional, round-the-clock care units    1.5. Other social welfare and health care personnel providing urgent care    In group 1.5, a limited number of social welfare and health care personnel working in functions that are considered urgent and critical by the region can be vaccinated against COVID-19. These functions are essential for guaranteeing the patientsâ statutory right to urgent treatment.    Such groups of essential personnel include:    Acute psychiatry unit personnel  Essential staff for units providing urgent care (such as round-the-clock emergency clinics and daytime emergency clinics)  Surgical and operative unit personnel providing emergency or urgent care  Personnel providing emergency or urgent care at wards  Personnel dealing with births  Personnel at emergency social work for substance abuse   Personnel at emergency services for child welfare  1.6. Election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting    As of 19 April 2021, according to an amendment to the Government decree, the election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting in the 2021 municipal elections will be treated as section 1 of the vaccination order.    This group includes the chairpersons, vice-chairpersons, members and deputy members of the electoral committees referred to in section 15 of the Election Act (714/1998) and the electoral commissioners responsible for at-home voting referred to in section 17.    Election boards are not included in this group.    2. The elderly, and persons with underlying conditions that predispose to severe COVID-19  Elderly persons are at the greatest risk for severe COVID-19 disease. Certain underlying conditions also predispose to severe COVID-19.    2.1. = 80-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*                  2.2. 75â79-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*    2.3. 70â74-year-olds, and carers living in the same household    2.4. 12â69-year-olds with a highly predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    2.5. 12â69-year-olds with a predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    * When vaccinating persons aged 70 or over, all those aged 70 or over living in the same household can be vaccinated at the same time when the oldest member of the household is eligible for vaccination, if this is feasible with regard to practical arrangements. Such groups of essential personnel include:    Acute psychiatry unit personnel  Essential staff for units providing urgent care (such as round-the-clock emergency clinics and daytime emergency clinics)  Surgical and operative unit personnel providing emergency or urgent care  Personnel providing emergency or urgent care at wards  Personnel dealing with births  Personnel at emergency social work for substance abuse   Personnel at emergency services for child welfare  1.6. Election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting    As of 19 April 2021, according to an amendment to the Government decree, the election commissions and election commissioners responsible for at-home voting in the 2021 municipal elections will be treated as section 1 of the vaccination order.    This group includes the chairpersons, vice-chairpersons, members and deputy members of the electoral committees referred to in section 15 of the Election Act (714/1998) and the electoral commissioners responsible for at-home voting referred to in section 17.    Election boards are not included in this group.    2. The elderly, and persons with underlying conditions that predispose to severe COVID-19  Elderly persons are at the greatest risk for severe COVID-19 disease. Certain underlying conditions also predispose to severe COVID-19.    2.1. = 80-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*                  2.2. 75â79-year-olds, and carers and elderly people living in the same household*    2.3. 70â74-year-olds, and carers living in the same household    2.4. 12â69-year-olds with a highly predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    2.5. 12â69-year-olds with a predisposing condition for severe coronavirus disease    * When vaccinating persons aged 70 or over, all those aged 70 or over living in the same household can be vaccinated at the same time when the oldest member of the household is eligible for vaccination, if this is feasible with regard to practical arrangements.    THL recommends that persons in terminal care should not be vaccinated. A decision on the vaccination of persons with fragile health is always made on a case-by-case basis in cooperation with the treating physician, the person being vaccinated and their family members.    Coronavirus vaccination order for risk groups    Press release 5.2.2021: THL has detailed medical risk groups for coronavirus vaccines     3. Others  According to a Government decree that entered into force on 19 April 2021, the rest of the population will be vaccinated by age group starting from the oldest age group.    3.1. 60â69-year-olds    3.2. 50â59-year-olds    3.3. 40â49-year-olds    3.4. 30â39-year-olds    3.5. 16â29-year-olds    3.5. 12â15-year-olds    Social welfare and health care personnel not included in groups 1.1â1.5 are vaccinated based on age along with the rest of the population.     Children under the age of 12 are not yet vaccinated, as no coronavirus vaccine in use has yet been authorised for children under that age. From 15 November, all Departments move to Level 2/Yellow health protocol irrespective of the incidence rate of Covid-19 in the local population, with facial coverings required for all Elementary school pupils. Previously, level 1 / green level restrictions were applied in Departments whose incidence rate was below a threshold of 50 per 100,000 inhabitants over a period of 5 consecutive days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211115032112/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20211115032052/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

All schools in France remain at the Level 2/Yellow level introduced on 15 November, irrespective of the incidence rate of Covid-19 in the local population. Facial coverings are required for all Elementary school pupils, and also for University students. Schools and Universities remain open, with barrier measures in place. https://web.archive.org/web/20211119230206/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education    From 29 November, rules concerning the closure of classes for a period of 7 days from detection of the first positive case will no longer apply to Elementary schools: students with a negative test within 24 hours will be able to continue to go to class. Middle school students from the 6th year on or after the age of 6 who have a complete vaccination schedule can continue face-to-face classes. Unvaccinated students must attend classes from home during the isolation period. https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075403/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

No change in policy, all schools remain at the Level 2/Yellow level introduced on 15 November, irrespective of the incidence rate of Covid-19 in the local population. https://web.archive.org/web/20211205060819/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

From 9 December, all primary schools are moved to Level 3/Orage level restrictions; facial coverings are required in playgrounds and contact sports are restricted. Masks continue to be required when inside for all staff and students aged 6 and over. https://web.archive.org/web/20211215185154/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

No change to policy, use of the Health Pass required for access to many workplaces - https://web.archive.org/web/20211118162943/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus and https://web.archive.org/web/20211116160514/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Use of the Health Pass is required for access to many workplaces by both employees and customers. On 26 November, two changes to the mechanism for maintaining validity of the Health Pass were announced:     - The validity of RT-PCR and antigen tests is reduced to 24 hours from 29 November 2021.  - From 15 December the "health pass" for anyone over 65 will no longer be active a booster vaccine has not been received within 7 months of the last injection or infection.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075403/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus  - https://web.archive.org/web/20211126150822/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075403/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus and  https://web.archive.org/web/20211126150822/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Use of the Health Pass is required for access to many workplaces by both employees and customers. From 9 December, discotheques are to be closed for a period of at least 4 weeks. The government recommends that 2 or 3 days per week of remote working are implemented in work environments where teleworking is possible, face-to-face meetings should be limited, and welcome and leaving ceremonies should be postponed.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20211207210635/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus  - https://web.archive.org/web/20211209195104/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

No change in policy, use of the health pass is required to access many places or events where people gather  - https://web.archive.org/web/20211118162943/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus and https://web.archive.org/web/20211116160514/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

No change in policy, public transport is available without restriction for local travel, but use of the Health Pass is required for long-distance journeys on any form of public transport - https://web.archive.org/web/20211116160514/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Long-distance journeys by interregional public transport including domestic flights, TGV, IntercitÃ©s and night trains and non-contracted interregional buses require use of the Health Pass. Other modes of transport, in particular public transport, are excluded from the application of the Pass. https://web.archive.org/web/20211126150822/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire

Public transport is available throughout France, but access to long-distance travel on public transport requires use of the Health Pass. https://web.archive.org/web/20211215185255/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/pass-sanitaire
There is no stay at home policy in place in metropolitan France - https://web.archive.org/web/20211118162943/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

No change in policy, entry to France remains controlled depending on the vaccination status, reason for traveling, and country of traveler origin. Origin countries are categorised as Green/Orange/Red depending on Covid-19 prevalence.     Ukraine was added to the list of Red category countries on 13 November. The list is now as follows:     - "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, Chile, comoros, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, the United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    - "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which there is active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.    - "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname, Turkey and Ukraine.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211119231143/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

No change in policy, entry to France remains controlled depending on the vaccination status, reason for traveling, and country of traveler origin. Origin countries are categorised as Green/Orange/Red depending on Covid-19 prevalence.     Belarus was added to the list of Red category countries on 23 November. The list is now as follows:     - "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, Chile, comoros, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, the United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    - "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which there is active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.    - "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname, Turkey and Ukraine.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211123221056/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19#nav-main-menu

No change in policy, entry to France remains controlled depending on the vaccination status, reason for traveling, and country of traveler origin. Origin countries are categorised as Green/Orange/Red depending on Covid-19 prevalence.     Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, and Zimbabwe were added to the list of Red category countries on 27 November, and flights between France and those countries were suspecnded between 27 November and 3 December (https://web.archive.org/web/20211202211842/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/deplacements)     The list is now as follows:     - "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, Chile, comoros, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, the United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    - "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which there is active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.    - "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Botswana, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Eswatini, Georgia, Lesotho, Moldova, Montenegro, Mozambique, Namibia, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, South Africa, Suriname, Turkey, Ukraine and Zimbabwe.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075535/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19#main

From 4 December at midnight, any person entering French territory from a country outside the European area must present a negative PCR or antigen test of less than 48 hours. The time for antigen tests for travel from scarlet red countries is 24 hours (see below).    "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, the Comoros, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.    "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname, Turkey and Ukraine.    As a precautionary measure, and pending additional data on the Omicron variant, a category of "scarlet red" countries is created: particularly active circulation of the virus and/or discovery of a variant likely to present a risk of increased transmissibility or immune escape. These are: Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe.    The ability to travel from or to French territory depends on this classification and the vaccination status of travelers, for complete details see https://web.archive.org/web/20211204173746/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 12 December, the classification of countries is as follows:     Green: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, the Comoros, South Korea, the United Arab Emirates, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay and Vanuatu.  Orange: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.  Red: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus with the presence of variants of concern is observed. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Mauritius, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname, Turkey and Ukraine.  Scarlet Red:  countries/territories in which a particularly active circulation of the virus is observed and/or the discovery of a variant likely to present a risk of increased transmissibility or immune escape. These are: Botswana, Eswatini, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe.    Details of the travel controls imposed per category are contained at https://web.archive.org/web/20211217002052/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 00:00 on 18 December, new rules impact travel between the United Kingdom and France due to prevalence of the Omicron variant in the UK. All travellers twelve years of age or older, regardless of vaccination status, from the United Kingdom:    - are subject to the regime of compelling reasons,the list of which is specified in the certificate of travel and travel drawn up by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France and return to their residence in the United Kingdom: french people and their spouses and children;  - must present a negative PCR or antigen (TAG) test taken less than 24 hours before flight boarding;  - must register before departure on the eOS-COVID digital platform  (https://web.archive.org/web/20211202154207/https://passager.serveureos.org/);  - may be subject to an antigen test on arrival;  - will be subject to mandatory isolation for 10 days, supervised and controlled by the security forces. This isolation obligation may be lifted from 48 hours, subject to a negative PCR or antigen test.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20211218000501/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays-destination/royaume-uni/    Restrictions for travelers from other countries remain as per the update of 12 December - https://web.archive.org/web/20211217002052/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

Vaccination is universally available to people aged over 12 years and two months. From 15 December, vaccination is available to children aged between 5 and 11 who are overweight or who have an underlying medical condition.     Vaccination booster is open to all people aged 18 and over from five months after the last injection or infection with Covid-19.    As of December 15, 2021, the rules relating to the "health pass" are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have made their recall, from the moment they are eligible (5 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 8 additional weeks maximum.    People aged 80 and over are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211207123504/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

In addition to the protections afforded to the general population, vaccination is mandatory for all people in contact with frail and elderly people, including caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers.     On 9 November, President Macron announced that it would be mandatory for people aged 65 and over who have been vaccinated with the Janssen (Johnson & Johnson) vaccine

In addition to the protections afforded to the general population, vaccination is mandatory for all people in contact with frail and elderly people, including caregivers, non-caregivers, professionals and volunteers.     From December 15, rules for the Health Pass are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have received a booster vaccine, from the moment they are eligible (i.e. 6 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 4 additional weeks maximum. Beyond this time, their QR code will be deactivated automatically.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211128075648/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Updated 3. November 2021  All travellers should be tested two days after arrival to the Faroe Islands.    Mandatory testing upon arrival to the Faroe Islands:  In addition to the recommendations above, the Epidemic Commission will require corona tests from all travellers who are unable to present a valid COVID Certificate. That is persons, who have not been fully vaccinated, and cannot present a valid corona test (not older than 72 hours) or have not been previously infected by corona (antibody test) must all be tested upon arrival in the Faroe Islands. This will apply from 15th of November 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211129054842/https://korona.fo/current-recommendations?_l=en

If you have symptoms:  If you are experiencing any of the symptoms mentioned above - whether these are common or uncommon - and/or have been in close contact with someone who has been infected by COVID19, you should first call your local doctor on weekdays between 08:00 and 16:00. If you do not have an assigned GP in your municipality, you should contact any local GP in your area.    After 16:00 on weekdays and during weekends you should call the after-hours GP service on 1870.    To avoid possible further infection, do not go to your doctor in person.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211123172302/https://korona.fo/symptoms?_l=en

If you have been in direct contact with a person who has tested positive for COVID-19, you should quarantine for seven days, counting from the date of the exposure. You will be contacted by the Chief Medical Officer.  To reduce the risk of the new Omicron variant spreading in the Faroe Islands, quarantine measures are being extended. This means that everyone who has been in contact with an infected person â i.e. secondary contacts â will be quarantined, regardless of vaccine received or previous infection status.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211210234418/https://korona.fo/270?_l=en

Friday 26 November 2021    Travellers arriving in England from several southern African countries will have to quarantine amid warnings over a new coronavirus variant.    UK Health Secretary Sajid Javid said from 12:00 GMT on Friday six countries would be added to the red list, with flights being temporarily banned.    One expert described the variant, known as B.1.1.529, as "the worst one we've seen so far", and there is concern it has the potential to evade immunity.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211126015008/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-59424269

The UK is removing all countries from its red travel list, just weeks after reactivating the list in response to the new Omicron variant.    As of tomorrow, 15 December, people arriving from 11 African countries will no longer need to stay in one of the government-run quarantine hotels.    People currently in a UK quarantine hotel will also be allowed to leave early, as long as they do not test positive for COVID-19.    However all current testing requirements will remain in place, Transport Secretary Grant Shapps confirmed on Twitter this afternoon.    he UK recently updated its travel rules, stipulating that all arrivals must now show a negative pre-departure PCR or lateral flow test that was taken within 48 hours of arriving.    This is in addition to a day 2 PCR test, which both UK citizens and visitors must await the results of in isolation. The rules vary for unvaccinated travellers.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211215095343/https://www.euronews.com/travel/2021/12/14/uk-travel-all-countries-removed-from-the-uk-s-red-quarantine-list

Indoor entertainment venues, restaurants, bars and cafes will only be accessible to vaccinated or recently recovered customers, with verification checks conducted at entrances through an app that scans COVID-19 certificates.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211105110420/https://apnews.com/article/europe-business-health-greece-coronavirus-pandemic-9656434341e8db7aa36fd73a2cbbb50c

no policy change     At level 4 (red) of the Epidemiology Charter country incorporated the Regional Units Kavala, Imathia, Pieria and Pella , while extending a special, local, measures in Regional Units Haryana and Argolis , after re-evaluation of epidemiological data the Committee of Infectious Diseases and the National Committee for the Protection of Public Health against the Covid-19 coronavirus in the context of the epidemiological surveillance of the country by Regional Unit and Municipality on a weekly basis.    At the same time, level 3 (orange) includes the Regional Units of Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Heraklion , as well as the Municipality of Ikaria .    It is reminded that the measures in force are the following:    Traffic ban from 01:00 in the evening until 06:00 in the morning, with the exception of work and serious health reasons.  Prohibition of music around the clock in stores of health interest and entertainment.  The measures are valid from tomorrow, Friday 17 September at 06.00 until Friday 24 September at 6:00 .    It is also reminded that in these areas, as well as in the whole territory, it is forbidden to hold any form of events in exchange for any form of exchange, with the physical presence of a crowd of more than twenty (20) people in a private, non-professional space . The administrative fine in case of violation amounts from 50,000 to 200,000 euros for the lessee or concessionaire of the private, non-professional space, in which the said event took place or takes place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210919221253/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/simantika-themata/sto-epipedo-4-toy-epidimiologikoy-harti-tis-horas-kavala-imathia-pieria-kai-pella

no policy change     Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210802101710/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

Schools open with extra restrictions in place. Masks and extra hygiene/ventilation rules in place. Students/teachers who have symptoms or test positive must self-isolate and show negative COVID-19 tests before returning to school.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211123235140/https://corona.nun.gl/da/arbejdsgiver/retningslinjer-for-grundskoler-fritidsaktiviteter-og-dagtilbud/  https://web.archive.org/web/20211119175013/https://corona.nun.gl/da/

Guidelines for when a child is suspected of being infected at a primary school, recreational activities, day care institution, etc.:  1. Persons with COVID-19 symptoms should isolate and get tested as quickly as possible.  2. Anyone with symptoms should be kept separate from the other children, pupils, students and employees until they can be collected or sent home, and all of the probable contact points must be cleaned (e.g. the seating in the classroom, doorknobs, handles, handrails etc., that the person or child with symptoms may have touched).  A negative PCR test will mean the tested person or child is no longer suspected of having COVID-19.  If it is ascertained there is infection among the pupils or teachers, the next steps will be clarified in collaboration with the municipality and the National Board of Health in Greenland (âLandslÃ¦geembedetâ) in accordance with the applicable rules for the area.    Basic principles for handling cases in relation to primary schools and day care institutions:  1.The day care institution or primary school should not allow any child or pupil who is infected or who is a close contact of an infected child or pupil from attending the institution or primary school.  2. The pupils can be tested, if required several times, rather than sending them home. The times for testing will depend on the specific case.  3. Children who do not have COVID-19 symptoms and whose parents do not want them to be tested, are recommended to remain at home for 14 days after their last near contact with the infected person.  4. Parents or other family members or people who live with the children who are near contacts, only need to pay extra attention to the infection prevention advice, including in relation to hygiene and airing out.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206122147/https://corona.nun.gl/en/at-the-workplace/guidelines-for-primary-schools-day-care-and-after-school-activities/

In Nuuk, Upernavik and Qasigiannguit , there is a requirement for vaccination against COVID-19 for people who are present in locations and associated areas that have public access. The requirements apply to all citizens over the age of 2. This means that children at the age of 2-12 do not have access unless they have previously been infected and have a positive PCR-test that is between 14 days and 12 weeks old. Shown below is information relating to the access requirement in Nuuk, Upernavik and Qasigiannguit. You must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 You are only allowed access to the following places if you are fully vaccinated against COVID-19: 1) Restaurants, cafes, pubs, discos and similar establishments and their adjoining outdoor areas. 2) Cultural institutions, including culture centres, cinemas, museums, exhibition halls, etc. 3) Community centres and similar establishments. 4) Libraries. 5) Indoor and outdoor sports facilities, including sports colleges and sports halls, swimming pools, gyms, football pitches, etc. 6) Hairdressers, massage parlours, beauty clinics and similar establishments. 7) Retail stores/shops that are not grocery stores.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206124730/https://corona.nun.gl/en/corona-passport-digital-eu-covid-certificate/vaccination-as-a-requirement-for-access/
